AuthorBlock: Catriona H M Jamieson. UCSD Moores Cancer Center, La Jolla, CA
SearchResultBody: Niche dependent pre-cancer stem cell detection and eradication
Title: Niche dependent pre-cancer stem cell detection and eradication

Abstract: One of the critical barriers to precision approaches for early cancer detection and interception is a limited understanding of the earliest molecular events associated with premalignant disease initiation and progression. A number of large-scale programs (federal, foundation and industry) have recently been launched across cancer types to develop a temporal and spatial atlas of the cellular and molecular changes associated with the transition of a premalignant lesion to invasive cancer. These efforts are yielding remarkable insights into the biology of premalignancy, that may ultimately lead to biomarkers for detecting aggressive pre-malignant lesions and novel therapeutic targets for disease interception that will transform cancer prevention.

AdditionalFields.Value: ++PR02-10 Prevention and treatment of premalignant lesions (intraepithelial neoplasia),,

SearchResultBody: Transforming early detection and interception via a pre-cancer atlas
Title: Transforming early detection and interception via a pre-cancer atlas

Abstract: Cancer medicine is undergoing a radical shift away from a reactive approach in patients presenting with symptomatic disease towards a more proactive approach aimed at early diagnosis, including at the pre-cancerous stage. Oesophageal adenocarcinoma develops gradually from the pre-malignant condition Barrett’s oesophagus which presents an opportunity to radically improve outcomes from this highly aggressive cancer. Work to unravel the: clinical-demographic and inherited risk factors; the cell of origin of this disease; and the molecular landscape of Barrett’s samples over time and space, in patients with different outcomes, is shedding light on the disease pathogenesis. Our improved understanding of the disease can be used to develop novel approaches to risk-based population screening and personalised prevention. One emerging paradigm is a triage system that comprises a risk assessment, followed by targeted screening using novel non-endoscopic detection devices coupled with molecular biomarkers to identify individuals at high risk of invasive cancer needing monitoring or preventative treatment. In patients with a Barrett’s lesion undergoing monitoring, molecular strategies can further distinguish between those with indolent disease versus those likely to progress. As we redesign clinical pathways for this disease we must be sure to maximise patient and clinician acceptability, affordability and ease of access to a given technology while balancing the risks for over-diagnosis and over-treatment.

AuthorBlock: Veronica Kinsler. The Francis Crick Institute, London, United Kingdom
SearchResultBody: Somatic mosaicism for classic oncogenic drivers: Unique insights into cancer
Title: Somatic mosaicism for classic oncogenic drivers: Unique insights into cancer

Abstract: The increased identification of individuals with an elevated risk of developing cancer based on inherited genetic susceptibility allows for targeted cancer interception opportunities. Understanding the molecular basis for cancer susceptibility creates the potential to disrupt the oncogenic process even after it has started. Individuals with pathogenic variants in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are at increased risk for the development of breast, ovarian, pancreatic, and prostate cancers. Work over the past decade has allowed for an understanding of the cells of origin of BRCA1 - related breast cancer and has led to a Phase III study of denosumab vs placebo to examine the impact of denosumab on breast cancer risk. The adjuvant study of the PARP inhibitor olaparib in high risk BRCA-associated breast cancer demonstrated an improvement in event free survival along with a favorable safety profile, paving the way for further work in the prevention space. Immunologic approaches have led to clinical trials using vaccines which will include healthy BRCA1/2 carriers. As our molecular understanding of BRCA haploinsufficiency improves, so too will our options for cancer interception. All of this work could lead to a halo effect with impact on sporadic cancer interception.
